title: Have you ever experienced transcendence? What did it change you? - Quora

response.answer_text: While I think the better suited responses may be around usage of weed and/or psychedelics in coordination with philosophy, I can provide a reflection on an experience I run into often. As you go about through your day and handle different tasks, it can be easy for your worldview to click into a specific model that works out for the most part. This worldview can include your relationships with other people (how much social credit is between you two, etc.) or how your endeavours function in general. As most worldviews tend to go, they fall apart at some point. Whether it’s a promise that doesn’t hold through or it’s behaviour from somebody that you didn’t anticipate. What usually occurs after that is you solving that particular instance and returning back to another worldview (it could be the same one however). My “transcendental experiences” would have to be when I observe whatever worldview or model I have from a spectator’s perspective while piecing things together sensibly. An example of this would be as I’m engaging with people and holding my viewpoints about where I stand in relation to other people. After a few mishaps and poor predictions, I come to the point of observation where (I know this may sound rather native and adolescent but I’d like to note that I’m only 17) people really do things for their own benefit/agenda. Not to tie that to rational egoism or the such but, this consideration has impacted my later models/worldviews. So, in short, thinking in a higher perspective about my beliefs and perspectives in ways that impact my future ones.

By definition, transcendence isn’t an experience. Here’s how Maharishi Mahesh Yogi discussed the issue: The state of Being is one of pure consciousness, completely out of the ﬁeld of relativity; there is no world of the senses or of objects, no trace of sensory activity, no trace of mental activity.There is no trinity of thinker, thinking process and thought; doer, process of doing and action; experiencer, process of experiencing and object of experience. The state of transcendental Unity of life, or pure consciousness, is completely free from all trace of duality. The state, sometimes called samadhi, is thought to emerge when the awareness-of activity in teh brain has temporarily shut down while still allowing long-distance communication between brain regions to continue. This allows the brain to rebalance itself without outside or intellectual interference. The aftermath of samadhi is sometimes called “Bliss” but one cannot be aware of the state while you are in it. Maharishi liked to call the aftermath, “the feeling that mother is home” — that all is right with the world.
